body:
Thank you for the feature request! We already discussing about it at #6, but it will be good timing to summarize the discussion about auto labeling (because auto-labeling would be one of the most important feature of next version doccano).

**Why we need auto-labeling?**

discribed at [Feature Idea](https://github.com/chakki-works/doccano/projects/2#card-16404963)

* For reducing human labeling cost drastically.

If labels are automatically set, only the users have to do is check & edit these.

**How to make auto-labeling model**

There are mainly 2 approaches.

1. Transfer learning setting
   * Prepare the pre-trained model, and transfer it by annotated data.
2. Semi-supervised setting
   * Train the model by annotated label gradually.

And we can use active learning when selecting annotation target data (more than select randomly).

|                                            | use trained model? | choose target data? |
|--------------------------------------------|--------------------|---------------------|
| 1. Transfer learning                          | o                  | x                   |
| 2. Transfer learning + Active Learning        | o                  | x                   |
| 3. Semi-supervised learning (Few-shot)                   | x                  | x                   |
| 4. Semi-supervised learning + Active Learning | x                  | o                   |

In recent research, the effectiveness of semi-supervised/active learning setting is a little problematic.

* [How transferable are the datasets collected by active learners?](https://arxiv.org/abs/1807.04801)
* [When Semi-Supervised Learning Meets Transfer Learning: Training Strategies, Models and Datasets](https://arxiv.org/abs/1812.05313)
* [Realistic Evaluation of Deep Semi-Supervised Learning Algorithms](https://arxiv.org/abs/1804.09170)

So we have to think about how to implement auto-labeling carefully.

**How to cooperate auto-labeling model**

doccano is based on Web-API based architecture, so you can label the data by external model from API. 

[example here](https://github.com/chakki-works/doccano/issues/6#issuecomment-489924577)

Something else that might be worth exploring: using stream processing might make a lot of sense for actual deployment. Stream processing frameworks like Kafka give the user flexibility to window a certain number of events (like `LabeledSentenceIngressed`) and after the window size has been met, retrain in a minibatch. It also allows you to easily do A/B testing or blue-green deployments of models. This might not be realistic for existing users, though, since kafka is a big dependency.

Instead of directly depending on Kafka, I'd recommend to instead use an abstraction framework like [kombu](https://github.com/celery/kombu) which lets the developer pick from a wide range of queue implementations such as e.g. AWS SQS, Azure ServiceBus, RabbitMQ, Redis, SQLite, etc.

I'd also really like to see this feature.

If you've never used Rasa/Rasa-X, it may be worth checking out how their platform handles the user workflow around retraining/reapplication of new models on annotated chat text.  I found it to be very intuitive.  They've developed a specialized few-shot learning model that does appear to work as promised.

issue.title: Auto-labeling implementation

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
Implementation of a solution for auto-labeling (sequence labelling projects only) as discussed in https://github.com/chakki-works/doccano/issues/191

- Solution based on spaCy‚Äôs ner module (multi-language)

- New button that allows an admin to start auto-labeling (and removes unapproved annotations)

- For now, if a document has no annotation, it will never be described as ‚Äòvalidated‚Äô. I propose  an other way to define a document as ‚Äòvalidated‚Äô : a document is ‚Äòvalidated' when it has been approved by an admin. I changed this behaviour because otherwise we couldn‚Äôt differentiate documents labeled automatically from others. 


Possible improvements :

- Add a shortcut to quickly validate one document (Enter?)

- Currently, the labels suggested by the algorithm are saved as if they were done by the admin clicking on the button; so a ‚Äònormal‚Äô user can‚Äôt change it. It would be better to add these new labels as if they were done by an other user (named ‚Äòcomputer' for example)

issue.title: Auto-labeling feature. Is it available?

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
Hello everyone!

I just saw self-advertisement in the doccano web-app saying _"Auto labeling
Auto labeling is one of the most powerful tools in creating annotated corpora. Machine learning model automatically annotates texts. You're only required to correct a few error annotations."_
I don't see how to turn it on, though. I found issue #412 , but according to that, the feature failed in tests. 
Is this useful feature available, or not?

Thank you!

issue.title: Improvement Idea for doccano

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
**Please read this issue when you want to add the feature to doccano**  
**Please upvote üëç related issue that let us judge priority .**

We show üëç if someone upvote, and ü§© means over 10 vote

## Toward More Practical Annotation Tool

### Annotation

* Display
  - [ ] : Support HTML syntax in Document #35 üëç
* Filter
  - [ ] : Arrange Annotation Status and Filter by it #280 üëç
* Label
  - [ ] : Provide for setting the order of labels #816
  - [ ] : Group labels by the same color #477
  - [ ] : Support multiple kinds of label set #5 üëç
  - [x] : Display shortkey in labels selector (on Annotation page) #834
* Annotation
  - [x] : keyboard shortcut for approval button #718 üëç
  - [x] : A button to clear the markup. #631
  - [ ] : Automatically select the sequential characters in the sequence labeling task by the hover. #666
  - [ ] : Show context when annotation. #466 
* Navigation
  - [x] : Redirect to the specific page by id, not by offset. #540 üëç
  - [x] : "First" and "Last" buttons #615
* Productivity
  - [ ] : Display the who annotated the document #881
  - [x] : Support Comments when Annotating #1050
  - [ ] : Enable Stats view for non-admins #270 üëç
* Portability
  - [ ] : Project export and import #901

### Dataset

* Import/Export
  - [x] : Convert label to label-ID when exporting #295 ü§©
  - [x] : Import the exported annotation data and keep the all original info #482
  - [x] : Support JSON format (not JSONL) #454 üëç
  - [x] : Make maximum file upload (import) size configurable #708 üëç
* Management
  - [x] : Bulk Delete #523

## Toward Advanced Annotation Tool

### Task

- [ ] : Question Answering dataset #81 ü§©
- [ ] : Multiple choice question #464
- [x] : Multiple label in sequence labeling #19 ü§©
- [x] : Nested Named Entity Recognition #544 üëç
- [x] : Relation Annotation #233 üëç

### Auto-Annotation

- [ ] : Implements labeling functions (Weak Supervision) #224 ü§©
- [x] : Add Auto-labeling #191

## Toward Production Usage

* Deployment
  - [ ] : Helm chart #701 üëç
  - [x] : Support doccano v1.x on Heroku #811
* Security
  - [ ] :  [Proposal] Warn and/or fail if default admin's password hasn't been changed #857
  - [x] : Clarify how to set user own username/password in docker-compose for security #748
* Authentication
  - [ ] : Two factor authentication for admin and annotators #756
  - [ ] : Okta OIDC social login is not available #1255 üëç
  - [ ] : Google OAuth support #620 üëç
  - [ ] : LDAP-Support #560 üëç
* Annotation Workflow
  - [x] : Allow user to change another users' annotation #531 üëç
* Annotator Management
  - [ ] : Allow to assign more than one role in a project. #537
  - [ ] : Enhance Statistics: Compare Annotators #114 üëç
* Accessibility
  - [x] : Multiple language interface #479

body:
With [`doccano-client`](https://pypi.org/project/doccano-client/) released to PyPI, it is now possible to hand off the active learning part to an external actor (preferably with its own Django user to distinguish model annotations from user annotations), like a Jupyter Notebook on a remote machine (with GPUs). With a powerful machine available, it is not too much overhead to just periodically predict all to-be-annotated docs, instead of predicting the docs on the fly.

I made a generic PoC of such a set up for Sequence Labelling projects, which takes all checked docs, trains, and predicts all unchecked docs:

https://gist.github.com/ddelange/35d219991d60606dfff034a3985bb0d1

This way, the architecture does not grow as complex as [AlpacaTag](https://github.com/INK-USC/AlpacaTag), and the user keeps full control over hypertuning and model architectures etc.

Plus, the Doccano server doesn't experience extra load from the training/inference!

issue.title: [Feature] Auto Labeling Implementation

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
This PR allows users to label text automatically. I think this enables users to speed up annotation.

![](https://i.gyazo.com/20776641e232fa8102f82e1f7889d4f2.gif)

## How it works

This feature enables automatic labeling by calling the Web API from doccano. Therefore, you can use any commercial service (e.g. Google Natural Language API, Amazon Comprehend, Watson, etc.) or your own server for labeling, as long as you can call the API from doccano. Notice that there is no learning function for now. This is an issue for the future.

## How to use

### Configuration

1. Select "Settings" on the side menu.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6737785/108456951-e533f780-72b4-11eb-9a5b-cf557bf313d6.png)

2. Select "Auto Labeling" tab and press "Create" button.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6737785/108457020-08f73d80-72b5-11eb-9579-7ef5ba9e4c52.png)

3. Select a configuration template. Some tasks have predefined templates to simplify the configuration.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6737785/108457067-22988500-72b5-11eb-8620-409d37775120.png)

4. Enter the parameters required to use the API.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6737785/108457117-44920780-72b5-11eb-8590-5440455a5189.png)

5. Write a mapping template to extract labels from API responses. If you select the predefined template, you can skip this process.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6737785/108457186-6f7c5b80-72b5-11eb-84f7-7d1e9089590c.png)

6. Map the label fetched from the API to a label defined by you.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6737785/108457273-9fc3fa00-72b5-11eb-80da-05986ea4d957.png)

### Turn on the feature

1. Go to the annotation page.
2. Select the settings button.
3. Turn on the feature.

Notice that if you don't have any configuration, you can't use this feature.

## Future works

- Assigning a configuration to each user
- Allow the admin to set throttling for each user
- Allow merging of responses from multiple APIs
- Implementing the training feature
- Increase the number of the predefined templates(https://github.com/doccano/auto-labeling-pipeline)

close #191
